meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is your <vocabulary>right hand</vocabulary>! This word can also be used to mean <vocabulary>right arm</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>right-hand side</vocabulary>.
<vocabulary>Fourth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day four</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
Any number with a つ attached is a word that means "NUMBER Things." In this case, it's <vocabulary>four things</vocabulary>.
You have four and you have thousand. Multiply them together and you have <vocabulary>four thousand</vocabulary>.
What do you get when you have four tens? You get <vocabulary>forty</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is your <vocabulary>left hand</vocabulary>! This word can also be used to mean <vocabulary>left arm</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>left-hand side</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life," making this word mean "<vocabulary>to live</vocabulary>."
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fat</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to get fat</vocabulary>.

The kanji <kanji>rest</kanji> has a little hiragana attached, but it's nothing that would suggest it's anything but a noun (it is!). It means the same thing as the kanji, <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 休 means <kanji>rest</kanji>, so what's the verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to rest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take time off</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>stop</kanji> that's just a <kanji>rest</kanji> (aka not permanent) isn't a straight up stop. You're planning on continuing again. That's why this is a <vocabulary>pause</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>suspension</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>hiatus</vocabulary>.

This is a fairly formal word, and it's often used when an activity or a service is temporarily suspended. For example, you could use it to talk about a class being suspended, a machine suspending its operation, or a pop band going on a hiatus. Check out our common word combinations below for more example usages.

This is a <kanji>rest</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>, aka a <vocabulary>day off</vocabulary>. Depending on where you're from, you might also call this a <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>. It's basically any day you have off from work or school.

The kanji means <kanji>previous</kanji>. This is an adverb version of that word. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with. You can't start your sentences with "previous" but you can start it with "<vocabulary>First of all</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to start with</vocabulary>."

This is usually written without kanji though, so keep that in mind.

Everything that happened to you <kanji>previous</kanji>ly is just the <vocabulary>tip</vocabulary> of the iceberg, and the important stuff is <vocabulary>ahead</vocabulary> of you, in your <vocabulary>future</vocabulary>. So make sure you put that stuff <vocabulary>first</vocabulary>!

The original meaning of this word is the tip of something, like a pen or a finger. From that meaning, it's expanded into all sorts of meanings, like ahead, first, and future, depending on the context and where it is in the sentence. It can also mean "previous" in formal contexts (and we'll accept that meaning too, but we're not teaching it here because it's more advanced).
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> (remember that 々 just repeats the kanji before it) is the <vocabulary>month before last</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is <vocabulary>last month</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> isn't necessarily yesterday. It can be any recent day, which is why this word means <vocabulary>the other day</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Previous</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>... So we're talking about someone who has a previous life, or maybe previous life experience? When you have previous life experience, you can teach others about it, making you qualified to be some kind of <vocabulary>teacher</vocabulary>.

先生 is often used for school teachers, but it's also used to show respect to doctors, lawyers, authors, and other respected experts. It's used as a standalone word or a name ender like トム先生.

The <kanji>name</kanji> of this <kanji>person</kanji> is well known, but why? It's because they're an <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary> in their field, or a <vocabulary>master</vocabulary> of something. If you're an expert or a master of something, people are going to know your name — even if you're just an expert at being an idiot.

A <kanji>name</kanji> written in <kanji>letter</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>surname</vocabulary>. Back in the day your surname was the important name (it's your family name after all, and family was king back in the day). This is the name you'd write out in kanji... aka in letters. So, that's why this combination of kanji means "surname."
A <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> is simpler than it sounds. It's really just a <vocabulary>letter</vocabulary>, right? You're reading 文字 right now, in fact!

You learned 文字 means "letter (of the alphabet)" or "character." And what does the kanji character for <kanji>one</kanji> look like in Japanese? A <vocabulary>straight line</vocabulary>!

Think of this word as meaning "the 一 character." In Japanese, it's most often used to describe the straight line a person's lips make when they're pressed together in concentration, frustration, or silence.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: The Year Two Thousand And Eleven

meaning_mnemonic: It's the 2011 <kanji>year</kanji>. I think the meaning is pretty obvious. This just means <vocabulary>year 2011</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>2011</vocabulary>.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: By The End Of This Year
Before The End Of The Year
Before The End Of This Year

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Inside</kanji> the <kanji>year</kanji> means <vocabulary>by the end of the year</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>within the year</vocabulary>.

年内 is used to talk about things happening before the current year is over. It can also be used to talk about one's plans for <vocabulary>the rest of the year</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: By The End Of The Year

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>middle</kanji> sounds like it should be something like "the middle of the year," but it's not. Think of something that happens in the middle of the year and then all other parts of the year. It's just referring to everything within this year, which is how we get <vocabulary>year round</vocabulary>.

You'd maybe think this just means <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji>, but it actually means <vocabulary>first year student</vocabulary>. A second year student is a 二年生, and so on. Just think about how crazy the Japanese are about school. You can see why school is life, and not life itself, making this vocab word "first year student."

Someone of <kanji>few</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s is someone who's young. Since we already have 少女 for girls, 少年 means <vocabulary>boy</vocabulary>.

少年 is a bit of a formal term that often refers to a <vocabulary>young boy</vocabulary>, usually between childhood and adolescence, or sometimes to a <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary> in general.
The <kanji>past</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is just <vocabulary>last year</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>early</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>early</vocabulary>.

Essentially you have the kanji 早 twice, because 々 is the repeater kanji. When you do something doubly <kanji>early</kanji>, there must be some kind of urgency to it, right? So you need to take action <vocabulary>as soon as</vocabulary> you finish whatever it is you're doing.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You <kanji>enter</kanji> into the <kanji>energy</kanji>. When entering into (positive) energy, you are going <vocabulary>to take a liking</vocabulary> to something and <vocabulary>to be pleased</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary> with it. Just imagine yourself entering into some happy energy when you take a liking to something.

It's weird to think of having <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>. But, what gives you energy? You do it one time every couple of seconds. That would be taking breaths. So, "one energy" is <vocabulary>one breath</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>energy</kanji> that's a <kanji>part</kanji> of you at any given time is reflected in your <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>, aka your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>. What kind of energy is part of you right now? Good mood energy, or bad feeling energy? 

気分 refers to someone's mood or emotional state, and sometimes to how they feel physically. You'll hear it when people describe how they're doing in the moment, like 気分がいい (I feel good), 気分がわるい (I feel unwell), or 気分がのらない (I'm not in the mood).

If a <kanji>person</kanji> has a lot of <kanji>energy</kanji> then they're very charismatic and fun! What's another feature of charismatic / fun people? They are most likely <vocabulary>popular</vocabulary> as well.

What is the <kanji>origin</kanji> of your <kanji>energy</kanji>? It is your <vocabulary>health</vocabulary>. This word also means <vocabulary>energy</vocabulary>, and when it's used as an adjective it means <vocabulary>healthy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>energetic</vocabulary>.

What is the <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>? If you think about it, that's all the stuff that falls on us from the sky. Lightning, rain, snow, hail... What is all of that? It's the <vocabulary>weather</vocabulary>.
What is <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>? It is energy you put into reading - it is your studies! In order to have book energy, though, you have to be very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary>.

You have a <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>. What kind of energy would be a flat one? Probably a <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary> one. You'd also tell people about this flat energy by saying you are <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>okay</vocabulary>.
You have only <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>. No other books cross your mind. Only this one book. Why? Because you have such a <vocabulary>one-track mind</vocabulary>.
<kanji>one hundred</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s is how much? Multiply the two together and you get a <vocabulary>million</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>four hundred</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s you also have <vocabulary>five hundred</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>two hundred</vocabulary>.

What is <kanji>bamboo</kanji>’s <kanji>child</kanji>? That would be a baby bamboo. Because "baby bamboo" doesn't really make sense, we'll instead call this word <vocabulary>bamboo shoot</vocabulary>s. 

When this is written as 竹の子, the bamboo shoots are probably still growing in the ground. If they’re picked and cooked and ready to eat, the pronunciation is the same, but it’s usually written in other forms, such as タケノコ.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is actually more general than the English words <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>bug</vocabulary>, though. It covers things like worms and spiders, too, so in that sense it's more like <vocabulary>creepy-crawly</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have a <kanji>village</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>. That isn't someone dancing while wearing construction worker clothes, that's a <vocabulary>villager</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Just be aware that this word used alone can sound a bit rude. You'll learn a more neutral option very soon.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>fire</kanji>... what looks like flowers on fire? That would be <vocabulary>fireworks</vocabulary>. Totally makes sense, right?

When you have <kanji>flower</kanji>s that you can <kanji>see</kanji>, you are viewing flowers. But not just any flowers. What flowers do Japanese people love viewing? That's right, this word refers to <vocabulary>viewing cherry blossoms</vocabulary>.

The focus of 花見 is on the act of appreciating blossoming trees, often accompanied by outdoor gatherings, picnics, or parties. Although cherry blossoms are the most commonly associated flowers, the term can encompass other flower-viewing experiences as well.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Take A Look At Something

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>see</kanji> so the vocab here means <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to look</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to watch</vocabulary>.

Seeing, looking, watching — 見る doesn't care. No need to squint over word choice here.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's related to the meaning of the kanji 見 "see," but this one is about having someone else see something. In other words, it means <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>see</kanji>ing <kanji>way</kanji> is your <vocabulary>way of seeing</vocabulary> something. This is like when someone has a dumb opinion and you're like, "oh, okay, so that's one way of seeing it..."

When you <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>see</kanji> something, you're doing a <vocabulary>moon viewing</vocabulary>.

月見 is a traditional autumn event in East Asia where people admire the full moon and enjoy seasonal treats, which in Japan include moon-shaped dumplings, sweet potatoes, and chestnuts. 月見 also often pops up in the names of foods that resemble the moon in some way, like a 月見バーガー — a hamburger whose fried egg topping is playfully compared to a full Harvest Moon.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

ちゃん is the honorific you put on a child's name. So, who is this mysterious child you're calling <kanji>red</kanji>? When a baby is born, what color are they? You got it, they're all red. And, because you want to be nice and cute you add ちゃん to that. That's why あかちゃん is a <vocabulary>baby</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leg</kanji> or <kanji>sufficient</kanji>, and we're going with the "sufficient" meaning for this word! This word means <vocabulary>to be enough</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A <kanji>foot</kanji> is a <vocabulary>foot</vocabulary>, you know?

Although this word is more commonly used for feet, sometimes it can also refer to <vocabulary>leg</vocabulary>s. Now you've got a leg up in understanding 足!

You have something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. When something isn't sufficient, you have an <vocabulary>insufficiency</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shortage</vocabulary>.

This word is more commonly used in formal contexts. In more casual, everyday conversations, 足りない is often preferred to express something being insufficient.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>inside</kanji> is simply that, <vocabulary>inside the car</vocabulary>. This can be used for other means of transport too, so it can also mean <vocabulary>inside the train</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inside the bus</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>generation</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second generation</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>generation</kanji> is the <vocabulary>third generation</vocabulary>. Depending on the context, you can sometimes use this alone to say you're third generation Japanese. Usually, though, you'll want to specify whether you're third generation Japanese or another nationality.
主 means <kanji>main</kanji> so when you add に it becomes the adverb <vocabulary>mainly</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> isn't just a master. You have to think back to when they were making these kanji. Who was the master? It was the <vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary>. This head of household probably told servants what to do and was all bossy and stuff. He was the master person. 

Also, this often means <vocabulary>husband</vocabulary>. Because, I guess the head of household back in the day was the husband. Those sexist ancient people!

The <kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is basically a "way of doing" something. More simply put, this is the <vocabulary>method</vocabulary>. "What's your way of doing this?" No no no. "What's your METHOD." There we go.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you have an <kanji>other</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, you really have <vocabulary>another person</vocabulary>.

他人 has a sense of unfamiliarity or distance, and suggests that the person isn’t well-known, or is different from you or a specific group of people. It doesn't usually mean "another person" in the sense of an additional person, or another person distinct from the one you’re talking about.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Take A Picture of Something

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>copy</kanji> so you know this means <vocabulary>to copy</vocabulary>. You know this word means "to copy" because it ends with す. You're copying the documents you need to <reading>sue</reading> (す) someone who screwed you over.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word is generally added to the end of a number, as in 三号 ("number 3"). It can also go together with other words to give things like train car numbers, as in ２号車 ("car 2"), and room numbers. When used on its own, it indicates the edition number of magazines and the like.

The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>central</kanji>... that is really, really in the <vocabulary>center</vocabulary> if you ask me (and is very <vocabulary>central</vocabulary> as well). This is one of those "overdid it on the meaning" words.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same with a little hiragana sticking out. Because the hiragana doesn't really indicate what it is, it's okay to assume that they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>s are boring. They're the same. One day after another. That's definitely not your exciting weekends... that's your boring, flat <vocabulary>weekdays</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hit</kanji> so the vocab is <vocabulary>to hit something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to strike something</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to type</vocabulary>.

You can use this word to describe bumping a part of your body on something, hitting a ball or a nail, or typing on a keyboard. It can also describe hitting a person, but that use is less common and sounds a bit literary.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is simply… <vocabulary>one hit</vocabulary>!

一打 refers to a single impactful strike. It's often a hit in ball sports, but can also be a punch in boxing or a button tap in video games.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This is かき <kanji>ice</kanji>, which is <vocabulary>shaved ice</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>say humbly</kanji>, and this is just the verb form, <vocabulary>to say humbly</vocabulary>. You can also call this <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>, just remember that it's humble!

This is a very humble way to say "to say" so it's used in especially formal situations, and only to talk about yourself or your associates. Because of its formality, it's almost always in the ます form, which is 申します.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>plate</kanji>. Wait, is that it? Yep, that's it.
The meaning of this word is the same as the kanji, except it has an お before it, which just makes the thing you're saying elevate the other person more. Basically, it's more polite and awesome.

When you have something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>correct</kanji>, you have no justice. In fact, you have <vocabulary>injustice</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself being put in an unjust situation, and think about how not correct it is. It's probably <vocabulary>dishonest</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unauthorized</vocabulary> too.

This is a single kanji plus the hiragana るい. Words that end in い are usually adjectives, and this is no exception. What's the adjective form of <kanji>bright</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>.
You have a child cow. What do you think a child cow is? Probably a <vocabulary>calf</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>baby cow</vocabulary>.

This is a pretty old word, and in the olden days, everything was <kanji>cut</kanji> by <kanji>hand</kanji>, including <vocabulary>postage stamp</vocabulary>s. Having to cut thousands of <vocabulary>stamp</vocabulary>s each day by hand sounds incredibly laborious, so maybe that's why this word came to be associated specifically with stamps.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also use this word to talk about someone's <vocabulary>age</vocabulary>.
This vocabulary word is the same as the 'name' meaning of the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll have no trouble remembering this word as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>treasure</kanji> <kanji>stone</kanji> is a very valuable stone. What kind of stones are considered treasures? How about a <vocabulary>jewel</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>gem</vocabulary>?
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>red</kanji>? Why, it's <vocabulary>red</vocabulary>!
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>white</kanji>? <vocabulary>White</vocabulary>, of course!

When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>one hundred</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Two</kanji> times <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>days</kanji> is <vocabulary>twenty days</vocabulary>.

If you go to (ごと) a <kanji>circle</kanji>, you need to go to it <vocabulary>in its entirety</vocabulary>. That means you have to circle around the <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary> thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.

You often hear this word when talking about food – like when biting into a whole apple or accidentally swallowing a grape without chewing. But it's not just for food: you can also use it to talk about memorizing a whole book from beginning to end, for example.

You <kanji>exit</kanji> but you do it with かける added to it. Just think of that かける as you are exiting while being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want <vocabulary>to go out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. You go out in a cocky way!

This word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train 出かける'd.

If there is a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> it's going to fill up the <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>! Think about big energies you feel in the atmosphere: thunderstorms, tornadoes, the aurora borealis. Just remember, this is the atmosphere in the sky, not the atmosphere in a fancy restaurant.

You've already learned that 口 means "mouth" and here it's followed by the particle に, which pinpoints a location. The verb する means "to do" so you're doing something to your mouth! Logically enough, this expression is used to describe lots of actions that you do with your mouth. It's often used to mean <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>, but with an added descriptive nuance that you've said something accidentally or unexpectedly, maybe something you shouldn't have said! 🙊

It can also mean other things done with the mouth, like <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>!

You already encountered アメリカ in the previous level, so you should know that it means "America." Put <kanji>north</kanji> in front of this and you get <vocabulary>North America</vocabulary>, just like in English!

Note that 北アメリカ refers to the continent of North America, as opposed to the northern part of the USA. アメリカ on its own usually means the USA, but when it has "north" or "south" in front of it like this, it's always referring to the continents.
